Shall meet him like a Baſiliſque, and ſtrike him:
Love, put deſtroying flames into mine eyes,
Into my ſmiles, deceits, that I may torture him,
That I may make him love to death, and laugh at him.

sp.speaker: Ap.
sp.l: Caeſar commends his Service to your Grace.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: His ſervice? what's his ſervice?

sp.speaker: Eros.
sp.l: Pray ye be patient,
The noble Caeſar loves ſtill.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: What's his will?

sp.speaker: Ap.
sp.l: He craves acceſs unto your Highneſſe

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: No:
Say no: I will have none to trouble me.

sp.speaker: Arſ.
sp.l: Good Siſter:

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: None I ſay: I will be private.
Would thou hadſt flung me into Nylus (keeper)
When firſt thou gav'ſt conſent, to bring my body
To this unthankfull Caeſar.

sp.speaker: Ap.
sp.l: 'Twas your will (Madam)
Nay more: your charge upon me, as I honoured ye:
You know what danger I endured.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: Take this,
And carry it to that Lordly Caeſar ſent thee:
There's a new Love, a handſome one: a rich one:
One that will hug his minde: bid him make love to it:
Tell the ambitious Broker, this will ſuffer—

sp.speaker: Ap.
sp.l: He enters.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Caeſar.
sp.l: I doe not uſe to waite (Lady)
Where I am, all the dores are free, and open.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: I gheſſe ſo, by your rudeneſe.

sp.speaker: Caeſar.
sp.l: Ye are not angry?
Things of your tender mold, ſhould be moſt gentle;
Why doe you frowne? good gods, what a ſet-anger
Have you forc'd into your face? Come, I muſt temper ye:
VVhat a coy ſmile was there, and a diſdainfull?
How like an ominous flaſh it broke out from ye?
Defend me (Love) Sweet, who has anger'd ye?

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: Shew him a glaſſe; that falſe face has betraid me:
That baſe heart wrought me—

sp.speaker: Caeſa●.
sp.l: Be more ſweetly angry;
I wrong'd ye faire?

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: Away with your foule flatteries:
They are too groſſe: but that I dare be angry,
And with as great a god as Caeſar is,
To ſhew how poorly I reſpect his memory,
I would not ſpeake to ye.

sp.speaker: Caeſar.
sp.l: Pray ye undoe this riddle,
And tell me how I have vext ye?

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: Let me thinke firſt
VVhether I may put on a Patience
That will with honour ſuffer me: know, I hate ye,
Let that begin the ſtory: Now I'le tell ye.

sp.speaker: Caeſar.
sp.l: But do it milder: In a noble Lady,
Softneſſe of ſpirit, and a ſober nature,
That moves like ſummer winds, coole: and blows ſweetneſſe;
Shews bleſſed like her ſelfe.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: And that great bleſſedneſſe
You firſt reap'd of me, till you taught my nature
Like a rude ſtorm to talk aloud, and thunder
Sleep was not gentler to my ſoule, and ſtiller;
You had the Spring of my affections:
And my faire fruits I gave you leave to taſte of:
You muſt expect the winter of mine anger:
You flung me off, before the Court diſgrac'd me,
VVhen in the pride I appeard of all my beauty,
Appear'd your Miſtreſſe; tooke into your eyes
The common-ſtrumpet love of hated lucre,
Courted with covetous heart, the ſlave of nature,
Gave all your thought to gold: that men of glory,
And minds adorn'd with noble love, would kick at:
Souldiers of royall marke, ſcorne ſuch baſe purchaſe:
Beauty and honour are the marks they ſhoot at;
I ſpake to ye then; I courted ye, and woo'd ye:
Call'd ye deare Caeſar, hung about ye tenderly:
VVas proud to appear your friend.

sp.speaker: Caeſar.
sp.l: You have miſtaken me.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: But neither Eye, nor Favour, not a Smile
VVas I bleſſed backe; but ſhooke off rudely,
And, as ye had been ſold to ſordid infamy,
You fell before the Images of treaſure,
And in your ſoule you worſhip'd: I ſtood ſlighted,
Forgotten and contemn'd; my ſoft embraces,
And thoſe ſweete kiſſes you call'd Elizium,
As letters writ in ſand, no more remembred?
The name and glory of your Cleopatra
Laugh'd at, and made a ſtory to your Captaines:
Shall I endure?

sp.speaker: Caeſar.
sp.l: You are deceiv'd in all this,
Upon my life you are, 'tis your much tenderneſſe.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: No, no, I love not that way; you are cozen'd:
I love with as much ambition as a Conquerour,
And where I love, will triumph.

sp.speaker: Caeſar.
sp.l: So you ſhall:
My heart ſhall be the Chariot that ſhall beare ye,
All I have wonne ſhall waite upon ye: By the gods
The bravery of this womans mind, has fired me:
Deare Miſtreſs ſhall I but this night?—

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: How Caeſar?
Have I let ſlip a ſecond vanity
That give thee hope?

sp.speaker: Caeſar.
sp.l: You ſhall be abſolute,
And Reigne alone as Queen: you ſhall be any thing.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: Make me a maide againe, and then I'le hear thee;
Examine all thy art of VVar, to doe that;
And if thou find'ſt it poſſible, I'le love thee:
Till when, farewell, unthankfull.

sp.speaker: Caeſar.
sp.l: Stay.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: I will not.

sp.speaker: Caeſar.
sp.l: I command.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: Command, and goe without, Sir.
I doe command thee be my ſlave for ever,
And vexe while I laugh at thee.

sp.speaker: Caeſar.
sp.l: Thus low, beauty?

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: It is too late; when I have found thee abſolute,
The man that Fame reports thee, and to me:
May be I ſhall thinke better. Farewell Conquerour. Exit.

sp.speaker: Caeſar.
sp.l: She mocks me too: I wil enjoy her Beauty:
I will not be deni'd; He force my longing.
Love is beſt pleas'd, when roundly we compell him,
And as he is Imperious, ſo will I be.
Stay fool, and be advis'd: that dulls the appetite;
Takes of the ſtrength and ſweetneſſe of delight.
By heaven ſhe is a miracle, I muſt uſe
A handſome way to win: how now? what feare
Dwells in your faces? you loooke all diſtracted.

sp.speaker: Sce.
sp.l: If it be feare, 'tis feare of your undoing?
Not of ourſelves: feare of your poore declining:
Our lives and deaths are equall benefits,
And we make louder prayers to dye nobly,
Then to live high, and wantonly: whilſt you are ſecure here,
And offer Heccatombs of lazie kiſſes
To the lewd god of Love, and cowardize,
And moſt laſciviouſly dye in delights,
You are begirt with the fierce Alexandrians,

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.l: The ſpawne of Aegypt, flow about your Pallace,
Arm'd all: and ready to aſſault.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Led on
By the falſe and baſe Photinus and his Miniſters;
No ſtirring out; no peeping through a loop-hole,
But ſtraight ſaluted with an armed Dart.

sp.speaker: Sce.
sp.l: No parley: they are deafe to all but danger,
They ſweare they will flea us, and then dry our Quarters:
A raſher of a ſalt lover, is ſuch a Shooing-horne:
Can you kiſſe away this conſpiracy, and ſet us free?
Or will the Giant god of love, fight for ye?
Will his fierce war-like bow kill a Cock-ſparrow?
Bring out the Lady, ſhe can quel this mutiny:
And with her powerfull looks, ſtrike awe into them:
She can deſtroy, and build againe the City,
Your Goddeſſes have mighty gifts: ſhew 'em her fair breſts,
The impregnable Bulwarks of proud Love, and let 'em
Begin their battery there: ſhe will laugh at 'em;
They are not above a hundred thouſand, Sir.
A miſt, a miſt, that when her Eyes breake out,
Her powerfull radiant eyes, and ſhake their flaſhes,
Will flye before her heates.

sp.speaker: Caeſar.
sp.l: Begirt with Villaines?

sp.speaker: Sce.
sp.l: They come to play you, and your Love a Huntſup
You were told what this ſame whorſon wenching, long agoe would come too:
You are taken napping now: has not a ſouldier
A time to kiſſe his friend, and a time to conſider,
But he muſt lye ſtill digging, like a Pioner,
Making of mines, and burying of his honour there?
'Twere good you would thinke—

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.l: And time too, or you will finde elſe
A harder task, then Courting a coy Beauty.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Look out and then beleeve.

sp.speaker: Sce.
sp.l: No, no, hang danger:
Take me provoking broth, and then goe to her:
Goe to your Love, and let her feele your valour;
Charge her whole body, when the ſword's in your throat (Sir,)
You may cry, Caeſar, and ſee if that will help ye.

sp.speaker: Caeſar.
sp.l: I'le be my ſelfe againe, and meet their furies,
Meet, & conſume their miſchiefs: make ſome ſhift (Sceva)
To recover the Fleet, and bring me up two Legions,
And you ſhall ſee me, how I'le breake like thunder
Amongſt theſe beds of ſlimy Eeles, and ſcatter 'em.

sp.speaker: Sce.
sp.l: Now ye ſpeak ſenſe: I'le put my life to the hazard
Before I goe. No more of this warm Lady,
Shee will ſpoil your ſword-hand.

sp.speaker: Caeſar.
sp.l: Goe: come, lets to Councell
How to prevent, and then to execute.

sp.speaker: 1 Sold.
sp.l: Did ye ſee this Penitence?

sp.speaker: 2 Sold.
sp.l: Yes: I ſaw, and heard it.

sp.speaker: 3 Sold.
sp.l: And I too: looke'd upon him, and obſerv'd it,
Hee's the ſtrangeſt Septinius now—

sp.speaker: 1 Sol.
sp.l: I heard he was altered,
And had given away his Gold to honeſt uſes:
Cryde monſtrouſly.

sp.speaker: 2. Sol.
sp.l: He cryes abundantly:
He is blind almoſt with weeping.

sp.speaker: 3. Sol.
sp.l: 'Tis moſt wonderfull
That a hard hearted man, and an old Souldier
Should have ſo much kind moyſture: when his mother dyde
He laughed aloud, and made the wickedſt Ballads—

sp.speaker: 1. Sol.
sp.l: 'Tis like enough: he never lov'd his Parents;
Nor can I blame him, for they neere lov'd him.
His mother dream'd before ſhe was deliverd
That ſhe was brought abed with a Buzzard, and ever after
She whiſtled him up to th'world, his brave clothes too
He has flung away: and goes like one of us now:
Walks with his hands in's pockets, poore and ſorrowfull,
And gives the beſt inſtructions. —

sp.speaker: 2 Sol.
sp.l: And tells ſtories
Of honeſt and good people that were honourd,
And how they were remembred: and runs mad
If he but hear of any ungratefull perſon,
A bloudy, or betraying man—

sp.speaker: 3. Sol.
sp.l: If it be poſſible
That an Arch-Villain may ever be recovered,
This penitent Raſcall will put hard: 'twere worth our labour
To ſee him once againe.

sp.speaker: 1. Sol.
sp.l: He ſpares us that labour
For here he comes.

sp.speaker: Sep.
sp.l: — Bleſſe ye my honeſt friends,
Bleſſe ye from baſe unworthy men; come not neare me:
For I am yet too taking for your company.

sp.speaker: 1. Sol.
sp.l: Did I not tell ye?

sp.speaker: 2. Sol.
sp.l: What booke's that?

sp.speaker: 1. Sol.
sp.l: No doubt
Some excellent Salve for a ſore heart, are you
Septinius, that baſe knave, that betrayd Pompey?

sp.speaker: Sep.
sp.l: I was, and am; unleſſe your honeſt thoughts
Will look upon my penitence, and ſave me
I muſt be ever Villaine: O good Souldiers
You that have Roman hearts, take heede of falſehood:
Take heede of blood; take heede of foule ingratitude,
The Gods have ſcarce a mercy for thoſe miſchiefes,
Take heede of pride, 'twas that that brought me to it.

sp.speaker: 2. Sol.
sp.l: This fellow would make a rare ſpeech at the gallowes

sp.speaker: 3. Sol.
sp.l: 'Tis very fit he were hangd to edifie us:

sp.speaker: Sep.
sp.l: Let all your thoughts be humble, and obedient,
Love your Commanders, honour them that feede ye:
Pray, that ye may be ſtrong in honeſty
As in the uſe of armes; Labour, and diligently
To keepe your hearts from eaſe, and her baſe iſſues;
Pride, and ambitious wantonneſſe, thoſe ſpoyld me:
Rather looſe all your limbs, then the leaſt honeſty,
You are never lame indeed, till loſſe of credit
Benum ye through: Scarrs, and thoſe maimes of honour
Are memorable crutches, that ſhall beare
When you are dead, your noble names to Eternity.

sp.speaker: 1. Sol.
sp.l: I cry.

sp.speaker: 2. Sol.
sp.l: And ſo doe I.

sp.speaker: 3. Sol.
sp.l: An excellent villaine.

sp.speaker: 1. Sol.
sp.l: A more ſweet pious knave, I never heard yet.

sp.speaker: 2. Sol.
sp.l: He was happie he was Raſcall, to come to this
Who's this? a Prieſt?

sp.speaker: Sep.
sp.l: O ſtay, moſt holy Sir!
And by the Gods of Egypt, I conjure ye,
(Iſis, and great Oſiris) pitty me,
Pitty a loaden man, and tell me truly
With what moſt humble Sacrifice I may
Waſh off my ſin, and appeaſe the powers that hate me?
Take from my heart thoſe thouſand thouſand furies,
That reſtleſſe gnaw upon my life, and ſave me?
Oreſtes bloody hands fell on his Mother,
Yet, at the holy altar he was pardon'd.

sp.speaker: Ach.
sp.l: Oreſtes out of madneſſe did his murther,
And therefore he found grace: thou (worſt of all men)
Out of cold blood, and hope of gaine, baſe lucre,
Slewſt thine own Feeder: come not neare the altar,
Nor with thy reeking hands pollute the Sacrifice,
Thou art markt for ſhame eternall. Exit.

sp.speaker: Sep.
sp.l: Looke all on me,
And let me be a ſtory left to time
Of blood and Infamy, how baſe and ougly
Ingratitude appears, with all her profits,
How monſtrous, my hoped grace, at Court? good ſouldiers
Let neither flattery, nor the witching ſound
Of high and ſoft preferment, touch your goodneſſe:
To be valiant, old, and honeſt, O what bleſſedneſſe—

sp.speaker: 1 Sold.
sp.l: Doſt thou want any thing?

sp.speaker: Sep.
sp.l: Nothing but your prayers:

sp.speaker: 2 S.
sp.l: Be thus, and let the blind Prieſt do his worſt,
We have gods as well as they, and they will heare us.

sp.p: Come, cry no more: thou haſt wep't out twenty Pompeyes.

sp.speaker: Pho.
sp.l: So penitent?

sp.speaker: Achil.
sp.l: It ſeemes ſo.

sp.speaker: Pho.
sp.l: Yet for all this
We muſt employ him.

sp.speaker: 1 Sold.
sp.l: Theſe are the armed Souldier-leaders:
Away: and let's tot'h Fort, we ſhall be ſnapt elſe. Exit.

sp.speaker: Pho.
sp.l: How now? why thus? what cauſe of this dejection?

sp.speaker: Achil.
sp.l: Why doſt thou weepe?

sp.speaker: Sep.
sp.l: Pray leave me, you have ruin'd me,
You have made me a famous Villain.

sp.speaker: Pho.
sp.l: Does that touch thee?

sp.speaker: Achil.
sp.l: He will be hard to win: he feels his lewdneſſe,

sp.speaker: Pho.
sp.l: He muſt be won, or we ſhall want our right hand.
This fellow dares, and knows, and muſt be heartned,
Art thou ſo poore to blench at what thou haſt done?
Is Conſcience a comrade for an old ſouldier?

sp.speaker: Achil.
sp.l: It is not that: it may be ſome diſgrace
That be takes heavily; and would be cheriſh'd,
Septinius ever ſcorn'd to ſhew ſuch weakneſſe.

sp.speaker: Sep.
sp.l: Let me alone; I am not for your purpoſe,
I am no wa new man.

sp.speaker: Pho.
sp.l: We have new affairs for thee
Thoſe that would raiſe thy head.

sp.speaker: Sep.
sp.l: I would 'twere off,
And in your bellies for the love you beare me.
I'le be no more Knave: I have ſtings enough
Already in my breaſt.

sp.speaker: Pho.
sp.l: Thou ſhalt be noble:
And who dares thinke then that thou art not honeſt?

sp.speaker: Achil.
sp.l: Thou ſhalt command in Chief, all our ſtrong Forces
And if thou ſerv'ſt an uſe, muſt not all juſtifie it?

sp.speaker: Sep.
sp.l: I am Rogue enough.

sp.speaker: Pho.
sp.l: Thou wilt be more, and baſer:
A poor Rogue is all rogues: open to all ſhames:
Nothing to ſhadow him: doſt thou think crying
Can keep thee from the cenſure of the Multitude?
Or to be kneeling at the altar ſave thee?
'Tis poore and ſervile:
Wert thou thine own Sacrifice
'Twould ſeeme ſo low, people would ſpit the fire out.

sp.speaker: Achil.
sp.l: Keep thy ſelf glorious ſtil, though ne're ſo ſtaind,
And that will leſſen it, if not work it out
To goe complaining thus: and thus repenting
Like a poore Girle that had betraid her maiden-head—

sp.speaker: Sep.
sp.l: I'le ſtop mine eares.

sp.speaker: Achil.
sp.l: Will ſhew ſo in a ſouldier,
So ſimply, and ſo ridicolouſly, ſo tamely—

sp.speaker: Pho.
sp.l: If people would believe thee, 'twer ſome honeſty,
And for thy penitence would not laugh at thee
(As ſure they will) and beat thee, for thy poverty:
If they would allow thy foolery, there were ſome hope.

sp.speaker: Sep.
sp.l: My foolery?

sp.speaker: Pho.
sp.l: Nay, more then that, thy miſery,
Thy monſtrous miſery.

sp.speaker: Achil.
sp.l: He begins to hearken:
Thy miſery ſo great, men will not bury thee.

sp.speaker: Sep.
sp.l: That this were true!

sp.speaker: Pho.
sp.l: Why does this conquering Caeſar
Labour through the worlds deep Seas of toyls & troubles,
Dangers, and deſperate hopes? to repent afterwards?
Why does he ſlaughter thouſands in a Battell,
And whip his Countrey with the Sword? to cry ſor't?
Thou killdſt great Pompey: hee'l kil all his kinred,
And juſtifie it: nay raiſe up Trophies to it,
When thou heareſt him repent: (he's held moſt holy too)
And cry for doing daily bloody murthers,
Take thou example, and goe aske forgiveneſſe,
Call up the thing thou nam'ſt thy conſcience,
And let it work: then 'twill ſeeme well Septinius.

sp.speaker: Sep.
sp.l: He does all this.

sp.speaker: Achil.
sp.l: Yes: and is honoured for it;
Nay call'd the honoured Caeſar, ſo maiſt thou be:
Thou wert born as neere a Crowne as he.

sp.speaker: Sep.
sp.l: He was poore.

sp.speaker: Pho.
sp.l: And deſperate bloody tricks got him this credit.

sp.speaker: Sep.
sp.l: I am afraid you will once more—

sp.speaker: Pho.
sp.l: Help to raiſe thee:
Off with thy pining blacke, it dulls a Souldier,
And put on reſolution like a man,
A noble Fate waits on thee.

sp.speaker: Sep.
sp.l: I now feele
My ſelfe returning Raſcall ſpeedily.
O that I had the power—

sp.speaker: Achil.
sp.l: Thou ſhalt have all:
And doe all through thy power, men ſhall admire thee,
And the vices of Septinius, ſhall turn vertues.

sp.speaker: Sep.
sp.l: Off: off: thou muſt off: off my cowardize,
Puling repentance off.

sp.speaker: Pho.
sp.l: Now thou ſpeakſt nobly.

sp.speaker: Sep.
sp.l: Off my dejected looks: and welcome impudence:
My daring ſhall be Deity, to ſave me:
Give me inſtructions, and put action on me:
A glorious cauſe upon my ſwords point (Gentlemen)
And let my wit, and valour work: you will raiſe me,
And make me out-dare all my miſeries?

sp.speaker: Pho.
sp.l: All this, and all thy wiſhes.

sp.speaker: Sep.
sp.l: Uſe me then,
Womaniſh feare farewell: I'le never melt more,
Lead on, to ſome great thing, to weale my ſpirit:
I cut the Cedar Pompey, and I'le fell
This huge Oake Caeſar too.

sp.speaker: Pho.
sp.l: Now thou ſingſt ſweetly:
And Ptolomy ſhall crowne thee for thy ſervice: (Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Achil.
sp.l: He's well wrought: put him on apace for cooling.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: THe tumult ſtill encreaſes.

sp.speaker: Caeſar.
sp.l: O my fortune!
My lu●●full folly rather! but 'tis well,
And worthily I am made a bondmans prey,
That after all my glorious victoryes,
In which I paſſ'd ſo many ſeas of dangers:
When all the Elements conſpir'd againſt me,
Would yeild up the dominion of this head
To any mortall power; ſo blinde and ſtupid:
To truſt theſe baſe Egyptians, that proclaim'd
Their per●uries, in noble Pompeys death,
And yet that could not warn me.

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.l: Be ſtill, Caeſar,
Who ever lov'd to exerciſe his fate,
Where danger look't moſt dreadfull.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: If you fall,
Fall not alone: let the King and his Siſter
Be buried in your ruines: on my life
They both are guilty: reaſon may aſſure you
Photinus nor Achillas durſt attempt you,
Or ſhake one Dart, or Sword, aim'd at your ſafety,
Without their warrant.

sp.speaker: Caeſar.
sp.l: For the young King I know not
How he may be miſſed; but for his Siſter
(Unequall'd Cleopatra) 'twere a kinde
Of blaſphemy to doubt her: ougly treaſon
Durſt never dwell in ſuch a glorious building,
Nor can ſo cleare and great a ſpirit, as hers is,
Admit of falſehood.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Let us ſeize on him then:
And leave her to her fortune.

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.l: If he have power
Uſe it to your ſecurity, and let
His honeſty acquit him; if he be faſe,
It is too great an honour he ſhould dye
By your victorious hand.

sp.speaker: Caeſar.
sp.l: He comes: and I
Shall do as I finde cauſe.

sp.speaker: Ptol.
sp.l: Let not great Caeſar
Impute the breach of hoſpitality,
To you (my gueſt) to me; I am contemn'd,
And my rebellious ſubjects lift their hands
Againſt my head: and would they aim'd no farther,
Provided that I fell a ſacrifice
To gaine you ſafety: that this is not faign'd,
The boldneſſe of my innocence may confirme you:
Had I bin privy to their bloody plot,
I now had led them on, and given faire gloſſe
To their bad cauſe, by being preſent with them:
But I that yet taſte of the puniſhment,
In being falſe to Pompey, will not make
A ſecond fault to Caeſar uncompell'd
With ſuch as have not yet ſhooke off obedience,
I yeild my ſelfe to you, and will take part
In all your dangers.

sp.speaker: Caeſar.
sp.l: This pleades your excuſe,
And I receive it.

sp.speaker: Ach.
sp.l: If they have any touch,
Of juſtice, or religion, I will uſe
The athority of our Gods, to call them back,
From their bad purpoſe.

sp.speaker: Ap.
sp.l: This part of the pallace,
Is yet defenſible: we may make it good,
Till your powers reſcue us.

sp.speaker: Caeſar.
sp.l: Caeſar beſeig'd?
Oſtaine to my great actions: 'twas my cuſtome
An Army routed, as my feete had wings
To be firſt in the chaſe: nor walls, nor Bulworkes
Could guard thoſe that eſcap'd the Battailes fury
From this ſtrong Arme, and I to be encloſ'd
My heart! my hart! but 'tis necesſity,
To which the Gods muſt yeild, and I obey,
'Till I redeeme it, by ſome glorious way. Exeunt.

div.head: Scena Secunda.

sp.speaker: Pho.
sp.l: Ther's no retiring now, we are broke in:
The deed paſt hope of pardon: if we proſper
A will be ſtilde lawfull, and we ſhall give lawes
To thoſe that now command us: ſtop not at
Or loyalty, or duty, bold Ambition,
To dare and power to do, gave the firſt difference
Betweene the King, and ſubject, Caeſars Motto,
Aut Caeſar aut Nihil, each of us muſt claime,
And uſe it as our owne.

sp.speaker: Achil.
sp.l: The deed is bloody
If we conclude in Ptolomies death.

sp.speaker: Pho.
sp.l: The better
The globe of Empire muſt be ſo manur.

sp.speaker: Sep.
sp.l: Rome, that from Romulus firſt tooke her name
Had her walls watered with a Crymſon ſhowr
Draind from a Brothers heart: nor was ſhe rais'd
To this prodigious height, that overlooks
Three full parts of the Earth, that pay her tribute,
But by enlarging of her narrow bounds
By the Sack of Neighbour Cities, were made hers
Till they were Cemented with the Blood of thoſe
That did poſſeſſe 'em: Ceſar, Ptolomy,
(Now I am ſteeld) to me are empty names
Eſteem'd as Pompeys was.

sp.speaker: Pho.
sp.l: Well ſaid Septinius,
Thou now art right againe.

sp.speaker: Achil.
sp.l: But what courſe take we
For the Princeſſe Cleopatra?

sp.speaker: Pho.
sp.l: Let her live
A while to make us ſport: ſhe ſhall authorize
Our undertakings to the ignorant people,
As if what we do were by her command:
But our triumvirat Government once confirm'd,
Shee beares her Brother company, that's my Province:
Leave me to work her.

sp.speaker: Achil.
sp.l: I will undertake
For Ptolomy.

sp.speaker: Sep.
sp.l: Ceſar ſhall be my taske,
And as in Pompey I began a names
I'le perfect it in Caeſar.

div.stage: Enter (above) Caeſar, Ptolomy, Achoreus, Ap|pollodorus, Anthony, Dollabella.

sp.speaker: Pho.
sp.l: 'Tis reſolv'd then
Wee'l force our paſſage.

sp.speaker: Achil.
sp.l: See: they do appeare
As they deſir'd a parley.

sp.speaker: Pho.
sp.l: I am proud yet
I have brought them to capitulate.

sp.speaker: Ptol.
sp.l: Now Photinus?

sp.speaker: Pho.
sp.l: Now Ptolomy?

sp.speaker: Ptol.
sp.l: No addition?

sp.speaker: Pho.
sp.l: We are equall,
Though Caeſars name were put into the ſcale,
In which our worth is weighd.

sp.speaker: Caeſar.
sp.l: Preſumptuous Villaine,
Upon what grounds haſt thou preſum'd to raiſe
Thy ſervile hand againſt the King, or me,
That have a greater name?

sp.speaker: Pho.
sp.l: On thoſe, by which
Thou didſt preſume to paſſe the Rubicon
Againſt the Laws of Rome; and at the name
Of traytor ſmile, as thou didſt when Marcellus
The Conſull, with the Senats full conſent
Pronounc'd thee for an enemy to thy Country,
Yet thou wentſt on, and thy rebellious Cauſe
Was crown'd with fair ſucceſs: why ſhould we fear then?
Thinke on that Caeſar.

sp.speaker: Caeſar.
sp.l: O the gods! be brav'd thus?
And be compelld to beare this from a ſlave
That would not brooke great Pompey his Superiour?

sp.speaker: Achil.
sp.l: Thy glories now have touch'd the higheſt point,
And muſt deſcend.

sp.speaker: Pho.
sp.l: Deſpaire, and thinke we ſtand
The Champions of Rome, to wreak her wrongs
Upon whoſe liberty thou haſt ſet thy foote.

sp.speaker: Sep.
sp.l: And that the ghoſts of all thoſe noble Romans
That by thy ſword fell in this Civill warre,
Expect revenge.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Dar'ſt thou ſpeak, and remember
There was a Pompey?

sp.speaker: Pho.
sp.l: There is no hope to ſcape us:
If that againſt the odds we have upon you
You dare come forth and fight, receive the honour
To dye, like Romans, if ye faint, reſolve
To ſtarve, like wretches: I diſdain to change Exit.
Another ſyllable with you.

sp.speaker: An●.
sp.l: Let us dye nobly:
And rather fall upon each others ſword
Then come into theſe villains hands.

sp.speaker: Caeſar.
sp.l: That Fortune
Which to this howre hath been a friend to Caeſar,
Though for a while ſhe cloath her brow with frowns
Will ſmile again upon me; who will pay her,
Or ſacrifice or vowes, if ſhe forſake
Her beſt of works in me? or ſuffer him
Whom, with a ſtrong hand ſhe hath led triumphant
Through the whole Weſtern world, & Rome acknowledgd
Her Soveraign Lord, to end in gloriouſly,
A life admir'd by all? the threatned danger
Muſt by a way more horrid, be avoided,
And I will run the hazard: Fire the Pallace,
And the rich Magazines that neighbour it,
In which the wealth of Aegypt is contain'd:
Start not, it ſhall be ſo; that while the people
Labour in quenching the enſuing flames,
Like Caeſar, with this handfull of my friends
Through fire, and ſwords, I force a paſſage to
My conquering Legions. King, if thou darſt follow
Where Caeſar leads, or live, or dye a Free-man;
If not, ſtay here a bond-man to thy ſlave,
And dead, be thought unworthy of a grave. Exeunt.

div.head: Scena Tertia.

sp.speaker: Sep.
sp.l: I feele my reſolution melts againe,
And that I am not knave alone, but foole
In all my purpoſes. This Devill Photinus
Employs me, as a property, and grown uſeleſſe
Will ſhake me off againe: he told me ſo
When I kill'd Pompey: nor can I hope better
When Caeſar is diſpatch'd: Services done
For ſuch as only ſtudy their owne ends,
Too great to be rewarded, or return'd
With deadly hate: I learnd this principle
In his own Schoole: yet ſtill he fooles me: well:
And yet he truſts me; Since I in my nature
Was faſhion'd to be falſe, wherefore ſhould I
That kill'd my Generall, and a Roman, one
To whom I owe all nouriſhments of life
Be true to an Aegyptian? to ſave Caeſar,
And turn Photinus plots on his own head,
As it is in my power, redeem my credit,
And live, to lye, and ſwear again in faſhion,
Oh, 'twere a Maſter-piece? ha? — me Ceaſar,
How's he got off?

div.stage: Enter Caeſar, Ptolomy, Antony, Dollabella. Achoreus, Appollodorus, Souldiers.

sp.speaker: Caeſar.
sp.l: The fire has tooke,
And ſhews the City, like a ſecond Troy,
The Navy too is ſcorch'd, the people greedy
To ſave their wealth, and houſes, while their ſouldiers
Make ſpoile of all: only Achillas troops
Make good their guard: break through them, we are ſafe:
I'le lead you like a Thunder-bolt.

sp.speaker: Sep.
sp.l: Stay Caeſar.

sp.speaker: Caeſar.
sp.l: Who's this? the dog Septinius?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Cut his throat.

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.l: You barkt but now, fawne you ſo ſoone?

sp.speaker: Sep.
sp.l: O heare me,
What I'le deliver is for Caeſars ſafety,
For all your good.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Good from a moneth like thine,
That never belch'd but blaſphemy & treaſon, on Feſtivall dayes

sp.speaker: Sep.
sp.l: I am an altered man: altered indeed,
And I will give you cauſe to ſay I am a Roman.

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.l: Rogue, I grant thee.

sp.speaker: Sep.
sp.l: Truſt me, I'le make the paſſage ſmooth and eaſy,
For your eſcape.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I'le truſt the Devill ſooner,
And make a ſafer bargaine.

sp.speaker: Sep.
sp.l: I am truſted,
With all Photinus ſecrets.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: There's no doubt then,
Thou wilt be falſe.

sp.speaker: Sep.
sp.l: Still to be true to you.

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.l: And very likely.

sp.speaker: Caeſar.
sp.l: Be breife, the meanes?

sp.speaker: Sep.
sp.l: Thus Caeſar:
To me alone, but bound by terrible oathes
Not to diſcover it, he hath reveal'd
A diſmall vault, whoſe dreadfull mouth do's open
A mile beyond the Citty: in this cave
Lye but two houres conceal'd.

sp.speaker: Ant
sp.l: If you believe him,
Hee'le bury us alive.

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.l: I'le fly in the ayre firſt.

sp.speaker: Sep.
sp.l: Then in the dead of night, I'le bring you backe
Into a private roome, where you ſhall finde
Photinus, and Achillas, and the reſt
Of their Commanders, cloſe at Counſell.

sp.speaker: Caeſar.
sp.l: Good: what followes?

sp.speaker: Sep.
sp.l: Fall me fairly on their throates,
Their heads cut off and ſhorn, the multitude
Will eaſily diſperſe.

sp.speaker: Caeſar.
sp.l: O Devill! away with him:
Nor true to friend nor enemy? Caeſar ſcornes
To find his ſafety, or revenge his wrongs
So baſe a way: or owe the meanes of life
To ſuch a leaprous Traytor. I have towr'd
For victory like a Faulcon in the clouds,
Not dig'd for't like a Moale: our Swords, and Cauſe
Make way for us; and that it may appeare
We tooke a noble courſe, and hate baſe Treaſon,
Some ſouldiers, that would merit Caeſars favour,
Hang him on yonder turret, and then follow
The lane, this ſword makes for you. Exit.

sp.speaker: 1 Sold.
sp.l: Here's a Belt,
Though I dye for it I'le uſe it.

sp.speaker: 2 Sold.
sp.l: Tis too good
To truſſe a Cur in.

sp.speaker: Sep.
sp.l: Save me, here's gold.

sp.speaker: 1 Sold.
sp.l: If Rome
Were offered for thy ranſome, it could not help thee.

sp.speaker: 2 Sold.
sp.l: Hang not an arſe.

sp.speaker: 1 Sold.
sp.l: Goad him on with thy ſword:
Thou doſt deſerve a worſer end; and may
All ſuch conclude ſo, that their friends betray.

div.head: Scena Quarta.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: We are loſt.

sp.speaker: Eros.
sp.l: Undon.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Confuſion, Fire, and Swords,
And fury in the ſouldiers face, more horrid
Circle us round.

sp.speaker: Eros.
sp.l: The Kings command they laugh at,
And jeere at Caeſars threats.

sp.speaker: Arſ.
sp.l: My brother ſeizd on
By the Roman, as thought guilty of the tumult,
And forc'd to beare him company, as mark'd out
For his protection, or revenge.

sp.speaker: Eros.
sp.l: They have broke
Into my Cabinet: my Trunks are ranſak'd.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: I have loſt my Jewels too; but thats the leaſt:
The barbarous Raſcalls, againſt all humanity,
Or ſenſe of pity, have kill'd my little dog,
And broke my monkeys chaine.

sp.speaker: Eros.
sp.l: They rufled me:
But that I could endure, and tire 'em too,
Would they proceed no further.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: O my ſiſter!

sp.speaker: Eros.
sp.l: My Queen, my Miſtreſſe!

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Can you ſtand unmov'd
When an Earth-quake of rebellion ſhakes the City?
And the Court trembles?

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: Yes Arſino,
And with a maſculine conſtancy deride
Fortunes worſt malice, as a ſervant to
My Vertues, not a Miſtreſs: then we forſake
The ſtrong fort of our ſelves, when we once yield,
Or ſhrink at her aſſaults; I am ſtill my ſelfe,
And though diſ-roab'd of Sovereignty, and raviſht
Of ceremonious duty, that attends it,
Nay, grant they had ſlav'd my body, my free mind
Like to the Palm-tree, walling fruitfull Nyle,
Shall grow up ſtraighter, and enlarge it ſelfe
Spight of the envious weight that loads it with:
Think of thy birth (Arſino) common burthens
Fit common ſhoulders; teach the multitude
By ſuffering nobly what they feare to touch at:
The greatneſſe of thy mind does ſoare a pitch,
Their dim eyes (darkned by their narrow ſoules)
Cannot arrive at.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: I am new created,
And owe this ſecond being to you (beſt ſiſter)
For now I feele you have infus'd into me
Part of your fortitude.

sp.speaker: Eros.
sp.l: I ſtill am fearfull:
I dare not tell a lye: you that were born
Daughters, and Siſters unto Kings, may nouriſh
Great thoughts, which I, that am your humble handmaid
Muſt not preſume to ryvall.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: Yet (my Eros)
Though thou haſt profited nothing, by obſerving
The whole courſe of my life, learn in my death,
Though not to equall, yet to imitate
Thy fearleſſe Miſtreſſe.

sp.speaker: Eros.
sp.l: O, a man in armes?
His weapon drawn too?

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: Though upon the point
Death ſate, I'le meete it, and out-dare the danger.

sp.speaker: Pho.
sp.l: Keep the watch ſtrong, and guard the paſſage ſure
That leads unto the Sea.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: What ſea of rudeneſſe
Breaks in upon us? or what Subjects breath
Dare raiſe a ſtorme, when we command a calm?
Are duty, and obedience fled to heaven,
And in their roome, ambition and pride
Sent into Aegyt? that face ſpeaks thee Photinus,
A thing thy Mother brought into the world:
My Brothers, and my Slave: but thy behaviour,
Oppos'd to that an inſolent Intruder
Upon that Soveraignty thou ſhouldſt bow to,
If in the gulph of baſe ingratitude,
All loyalty to Ptolomy the King
Be ſwallowed up, remember who I am,
Whoſe Daughter, and whoſe Siſter: or ſuppoſe
That is forgot too; let the name of Caeſar
Which Nations quake at, ſtop the deſperate madneſſe
From running headong on to thy confuſion.
Throw from thee quickly thoſe rebellious armes,
Tnd let me read ſubmiſſion in thine eyes,
Ahy wrongs to us, we will not only pardon,
But be a ready advocate, to plead for thee
To Caeſar, and my Brother.

sp.speaker: Pho.
sp.l: Plead my pardon?
To you I bow, but ſcorn as much to ſtoop thus
To Ptolomy, to Caeſar? Nay the gods,
As to put off the figure of a man,
And change my Eſſence, with a ſenſuall beaſt:
All my deſignes, my counſels, and dark ends
Were aym'd to purchaſe you.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: How durſt thou, being
The ſcorne of baſeneſſe, nouriſh ſuch a thought?

sp.speaker: Pho.
sp.l: They that have power are royall: and thoſe baſe
That live at the devotion of an other,
What birth gave Ptolomy, or fortune Caeſar,
By Engines faſhiond in this Protean Anvill
I have made mine: and onely ſtoop at you,
Whom I would ſtill preſerve free to command me;
For Caeſars frownes, they are below my thoughts,
And but in theſe faire eyes, I ſtill have read
The ſtory of a ſupreame Monarchy,
To which all hearts with mine, gladly pay tribute,
Photinus name, had long ſince bin as great
As Ptolomies ere was, or Caeſars is,
This made me as a weaker tye to unlooſe
The knot of loyalty, that chain'd my freedom;
And ſlight the feare that Caeſars threats might cauſe,
That I and they might ſee no Sun appeare
But Cleopatra, in th' Egyptian Spheare.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: O giantlike Ambition! married to
Cymerian darkneſſe! in conſiderate foole,
(Though flatter'd with ſelve love) could'ſt thou beleeve,
Were all Crownes on the earth, made into one,
And that (by Kings) ſet on thy head: all Scepters,
Within thy graſpe, and laid downe at my feete,
I would vouchſafe a kiſſe to a no-man?
A guelded Evenuch?

sp.speaker: Phot.
sp.l: Faireſt, that makes for me:
And ſhewes it is no ſenſuall appetite,
But true love to the greatneſſe of thy ſpirit,
That when that you are mine ſhall yeild me pleaſures:
Hymen, though bleſſing a new married paire
Shall bluſh to thinke on, and our certaine Iſſue,
The glorious ſplendour of dread Majeſty:
Whoſe beames ſhall dazell Rome, and awe the world:
My wants in that kinde, others ſhall ſupply,
And I give way to it.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: Baſer then thy birth:
Can there be Gods, and heare this, and no thunder,
Ram thee into the earth?

sp.speaker: Pho.
sp.l: They are a ſleepe,
And cannot heare thee:
Or with open eyes,
Did Jove looke on us, I would laugh and ſweare
That his artillary is cloid by me:
Or if that they have power to hurt, his Bolts
Are in my hand.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: Moſt impious!

sp.speaker: Pho.
sp.l: They are dreames,
Religious fooles ſhake at: yet to aſſure thee,
If Nemeſis, that ſcourges pride, and ſcorne,
Be any thing but a name ſhe lives in me:
For by my ſelfe (an oath to me more dreadfull
Then Stix is to your Gods) weake Ptolomy dead,
And Caeſar (both being in my toile) remov'd
The pooreſt Raſcalls, that are in my Camp
Shall, in my preſence, quench their Iuſtfull heate
In thee, and young Arſinoe; while I laugh
To heare you howle in vaine:
I deride thoſe Gods,
That you thinke can protect you,

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: To prevent thee,
In that I am the Miſtreſs of my fate:
So hope I of my Siſter, to confirme it,
I ſpit at thee, and ſcorne thee.

sp.speaker: Pho.
sp.l: I will tame,
That haughty courage, and make it ſtoop too.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: Never:
I was borne to command and I will dye ſo.

div.stage: Enter Achillas and Souldiers, with the body of Ptolomy.

sp.speaker: Pho.
sp.l: The King dead? this is a faire entrance to,
Our future happineſſe.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: O my Deare Brother?

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: Weepe not Arſinoe, common women do ſoe,
Nor looſe a teare for him, it cannot helpe him:
But ſtudy to dye nobly.

sp.speaker: Pho.
sp.l: Caeſar fled?
'Tis deadly aconite to my cold heart:
It choakes my vitall ſpirits: where was your care?
Did the guardes ſleepe?

sp.speaker: Achil.
sp.l: He rowz'd them with his ſword:
We talke of Mars, but I am ſure his courage
Admits of no compariſon but it ſelfe,
And (as inſpir'd by him) his following friends
With ſuch a confidence, as you Eagletss prey
Under the large wing of their feircer dam,
Brake through our troopes, and ſcatterd 'em, he went on:
But ſtill purſude by us: when on the ſudaine,
He turn'd his head, and from his eyes flew terrour;
Which ſtrooke in us no leſſe feare, and amazement,
Then if we had encounter'd with the lightning,
Hurld from Joves clowdy brow.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: 'Twas like my Caeſar.

sp.speaker: Achil.
sp.l: We falne back, he made on, and as our feare
Had parted from us, with his dreadfull lookes,
Againe we follow'd: but got neare the ſea:
On which his navy anchord; in one hand
Holding a ſcroll he had, above the waves,
And in the other graſping faſt his ſword
As it had bin a trident, forg'd by Ʋulcan,
To calme the raging Ocean, he made away
As if he had bin Neptune: his friends like
So many Tritons follow'd their bold ſhowts,
Yeilding a chearefull muſique; we ſhowr'd darts,
Upon them but in vaine, they reach'd their ſhips,
And in their ſafety we are ſunck; for Caeſar
Prepares for war.

sp.speaker: Pho.
sp.l: How fell the King?

sp.speaker: Achil.
sp.l: Unable,
To follow Caeſar, he was trod to death
By the purſuers, and with him the Prieſt,
Of Iſis good Achoreus.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: May the Earth,
Lye gently on their aſhes.

sp.speaker: Pho.
sp.l: I feele now,
That there are powers above us: and that 'tis not
Within the ſearching policies of man,
To alter their decrees.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: I laugh at thee:
Where are thy threates now, (foole) thy ſcoffs, and ſcornes
Againſt the Gods? I ſee calamity
Is the beſt Miſtris of Religion,
And can convert an Atheiſt.

sp.speaker: Pho.
sp.l: O they come,
Mountaines fall on me! O, for him to dye
That plac'd his heaven on earth, is an aſſurance
Of his deſcent to hell; where ſhall I hide me?
The greateſt daring to a man diſhoneſt,
Is but a baſtard courage, ever fainting. Exit.

sp.speaker: Caeſar.
sp.p: Looke on your Caeſar; baniſh feare (my faireſt) You now are ſafe.

sp.speaker: Sce.
sp.l: By Ʋenus, not a kiſſe
Till our worke be done: the Traitors once diſpatch'd
To it, and wee'le cry aime.

sp.speaker: Caeſar.
sp.l: I will be ſpeedy. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: Farewell againe Arſinoe; how now Eros,
Ever faint-harted?

sp.speaker: Eros.
sp.l: But that I am aſſur'd,
Your excellency can command the Generall,
I feare the Souldiers, for they looke as if
They would be nibling too.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: He is all honour,
Nor do I now repent me of my favours;
Nor can I thinke nature e're made a woman,
That in her prime deſerv'd him.

div.stage: Enter Caeſar, Sceva, Antony, Dollabella, Souldiers, With the heads.

sp.speaker: Ars.
sp.l: He's come backe,
Purſue no farther; curb the Souldiers fury.
See (beauteous Miſtris) their accurſed heads,
That did conſpire againſt us.

sp.speaker: Sceva.
sp.l: Furies plague 'em,
They had too faire an end, to dye like Souldiers,
Pompey fell by the ſword; the croſſe, or halter
Should have diſpatch'd them.

sp.speaker: Caeſar.
sp.l: All is but death (good Sceva)
Be therefore ſatisfied, and now (my deareſt)
Looke up on Caeſar, as he ſtill appear'd
A Conquerour, and this unfortunate King
Entomb'd with honour, wee'le for Rome, where Caeſar
Will ſhew he can give Kingdome: for the Senate,
(Thy brother dead) ſhall willingly decree
The Crowne of Egypt, (that was his) to thee.

div.head: The Prologue.
div.l: NEw Titles, warrant not a Play for new,
The ſubject being old: and 'tis as true,
Freſh, and neate matter may with eaſe be fram'd
Out of their Stories, that have oft been nam'd
With glory on the Stage: what borrows he
From him that wrote olde Priams Tragedy.
That writes bis love to Hecuba? Sure, to tell
Of Caeſars amorous heates, and how he fell
In the Capitoll, can never be the ſame
To the Judicious: Nor will ſuch blame
Thoſe that penn'd this, for Barrenneſſe when they finde
Young Cleopatra here, and her great mind
Expreſs'd to the height, with us a Maid, and free,
And how he rated her Virginity.
We treat not of what boldneſſe ſhe did dye,
Nor of her fatall Love to Anthony.
What wee preſent and offer to your view,
(Ʋpon their Faiths) the Stage yet never knew.
Let Reaſon then, firſt to your wills give Lawes,
And after judge of them, and of their Cauſe.

div.head: The Epilogue.
div.l: I Now ſhould wiſh another had my place,
But that I hope to come off, and with grace.
And but expreſſe ſome ſigne that you are pleas'd,
We of our doubts, they of their feares are eas'd.
I would beg further (Gentlemen) and much ſay
In the favour of our ſelves, them, and the Play;
Did I not reſt aſſur'd; the moſt I ſee
Hate Impudence, and cheriſh modeſty.
